Modification_Detail.description: Updated schema version. Adding missing "investigation" references.

Changed inst LIDs from u:n:p:c:i:instID.scID to u:n:p:c:i:scID.instID Changed LIDs from urn:nasa:pds: to urn:esa:psa: And per "Guide toPDS4 Context Products" v1.7, changed all lidvid_reference to lid_reference

External_Reference.reference_text: Asmar, S.W., and R.G. Herrera, Radio Science Handbook, JPL D-7938 Volume 3, Jet Propulsion Laboratory, Pasadena, CA, 1993.
Asmar, S.W., and R.G. Herrera, Radio Science Handbook, JPL D-7938, Volume 4, Jet Propulsion Laboratory, Pasadena, CA, 22 January 1993.
Asmar, S. W., N. A. Renzetti, The Deep Space Network as an instrument for radio science research, NASA Technical Reports Server, 1993STIN...9521456A, 1993.
Asmar, S.W., R.G. Herrera, and T. Priest, Radio Science Handbook, JPL D-7938, Volume 6, Jet Propulsion Laboratory, Pasadena, CA, 1995.
Bird, M.K., S.W. Asmar, J.P. Brenkle, P. Edenhofer, M. Paetzold, and H. Volland, The Coronal-Sounding Experiment, Astron. Astrophys. Supp. Ser. 92, 425-430, 1992.

Bird, M.K., S.W. Asmar, J.P. Brenkle, P. Edenhofer, O. Funke, M. Paetzold, and H. Volland, Ulysses Radio Occultation Observations of the Io Plasma Torus During the Jupiter Encounter, Science, 257, 1531-1535, 1992.

Bird, M.K., S.W. Asmar, P. Edenhofer, O. Funke, M. Paetzold, and H. Volland, The structure of Jupiter's Io plasma torus inferred from Ulysses radio occultation observations, Planet. Space Sci. 41, 999-1010, 1993.

Bird, M.K., H. Volland, M. Paetzold, P. Edenhofer, S.W. Asmar, and J.P. Brenkle, The coronal electron density distribution determined from dual-frequency ranging measurements during the 1991 solar conjunction of the Ulysses spacecraft, Astrophys. J., 426, 373-381, 1994.

Bird, M.K., M. Paetzold, P. Edenhofer, S.W. Asmar, and T.P. McElrath, Coronal Radio Sounding with Ulysses: Solar Wind Electron Density Near 0.1 AU During the 1995 Conjunction, Astronomy and Astrophysics, 316, 441-448, 1996.
Deep Space Mission System / Telecommunications Link Design Handbook Document TMOD 810-005, Rev. E, Jet Propulsion Laboratory, Pasadena, CA.
Deep Space Network System Requirements / Detailed Interface Design, Document 820-13, Jet Propulsion Laboratory, Pasadena, CA.

Janardhan, P., M.K. Bird, P. Edenhofer, R. Wohlmuth, D. Plettemeier, S.W. Asmar, M. Paetzold, and J. Karl, Coronal velocity measurements with Ulysses: Multi-link correlation studies during two superior conjunctions, Solar Physics, 184, 157-172, 1999.
Karl, J., M. Paetzold, and M.K. Bird, Coronal Radio Sounding: Non-Gaussian Turbulence in the Source Regions of Slow and Fast Solar Wind, Geophys. Res. Lett. 24, 2881-2884, 1997.
Paetzold, M., and M.K. Bird, The Pioneer 6 Faraday rotation transients - on the interpretation of coronal Faraday rotation data, Geophysical Research Letters, 25, 2105-2108, 1998.

Paetzold, M., H. Porsche, P. Edenhofer, M.K. Bird, and H. Volland, Giotto Radio-Science Experiment: Expected Drag Deceleration and Spacecraft Attitude Perturbations During the Encounter with Comet P/Grigg-Skjellerup in July 1992, Astronomy and Astrophysics, 259, L15-L18, 1992.

Paetzold, M., M.K. Bird, P. Edenhofer, S.W. Asmar, and T.P. McElrath, Dual-Frequency Radio Sounding of the Solar Corona during the 1995 Conjunction of the Ulysses Spacecraft, Geophysical Research Letters, 22, 3313-3316, 1995.
Paetzold, M., J. Karl, M.K. Bird, Coronal radio sounding with Ulysses: Phase scintillation spectra in coronal holes and streamers, Astronomy and Astrophysics, 316, 449 - 456, 1996.

Paetzold, M., B.T. Tsurutani, and M.K. Bird, An estimate of large-scale solar wind density and velocity profiles in a coronal hole and the coronal streamer belt, Journal of Geophysical Research, 102, 25151 - 24160, 1997.

Tyler, G.L., G. Balmino, D.P. Hinson, W.L. Sjogren, D.E. Smith, R. Woo, S.W. Asmar, M.J. Connally, C.L. Hamilton, and R.A. Simpson, Radio Science Investigations with Mars Observer, Journal of Geophysical Research, 97, 7759-7779, 1992.

Wohlmuth, R., D. Plettemeier, P. Edenhofer, M.K. Bird, M. Paetzold, and S.W. Asmar, Measurememt of the Propagation Speed of Plasma Inhomogeneities in the Solar Corona Using an Uplink/Downlink Cross Correlation Method, Radio Science, 32, 617-628, 1997.
Woo, R., and S.R. Habbal, Extension of Coronal Structure into Interplanetary Space, Geophys. Res. Lett., 24, 1159-1162, 1997.

Woo, R., and S.R. Habbal, Comment on: 'Polar Plumes and Fine-Scale Coronal Structures - On The Interpretation of Coronal Radio Sounding Data' By Paetzold and Bird, Geophys. Res. Lett. 25, 1849-1850, 1998.
Woo, R., Detection of low-latitude plumes in the outer corona by Ulysses radio ranging measurements, Astrophysical Journal, 464, L95-L98, 1996.

Woo, R., J.W. Armstrong, M.K. Bird, and M. Paetzold, Variation of Fractional Electron Density Fluctuations Near 0.1 AU from the Sun Observed by Ulysses Dual-Frequency Ranging Measurements, Geophysical Research Letters, 22, 329-332, 1995.
Woo, R., J.W. Armstrong, M.K. Bird, and M. Paetzold, Fine-scale filamentary structure in coronal streamers, Astrophys. J. 449, L91-L94, 1995.

Instrument.name: Solar Corona Experiment for ULY
Instrument.description:
The Solar Corona Experiment (SCE) utilized radio science instrumentation for investigations related to the solar corona, specifically using elements from both the Ulysses spacecraft and the Deep Space Network (DSN). The Ulysses spacecraft was equipped with a telecommunications subsystem designed for dual-frequency radio science measurements. Launched without changes after its build date in 1986, the instrument included redundant transponders and a parabolic antenna that managed S-band and X-band signals.
The main objectives of the SCE included measuring coronal plasma density and properties during solar conjunctions and observing the Io Plasma Torus (IPT) near Jupiter. The spacecraft's capabilities allowed for precise measurements of electron content and variations, with significant findings from both the first and fourth solar conjunctions.
The DSN, consisting of three Deep Space Communications Complexes (located in California, Australia, and Spain), supported the SCE through various antennas and signal processing systems. The network was essential for tracking the spacecraft, receiving telemetry data, and conducting scientific investigations.
Calibration of the radio science instruments was carried out early in the mission, and the operational aspects required careful management of the antennas and subsystems to ensure quality data collection during key observations. The entire setup relied on a structured communication and processing system to support the scientific goals of the Ulysses mission.
